_exec_summary.SummaryText:
RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN - URETHANE POLYMERS INTERNATIONAL, INC.



EXECUTIVE SUMMARY



Urethane Polymers International, Inc. is a coating manufacturing company that uses Toluene Di-Isocyanate (TDI).  The facility receives and stores TDI in 55 gallon drums, which are located in a designated storage area.  TDI is used as one component for various materials that are produced at the facility.  Urethane Polymers International, Inc. management ensures that employees handling raw materials are trained in the proper handling methods and that safety precautions are implemented.

.

Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies 



Urethane Polymers International, Inc. has implemented a safety program to minimize the likelihood of injuries, accidents and releases to the environment. As part of this program, all Urethane Polymers International, Inc. employees who will be working with the hazardous materials are trained on the hazards of the materials.  Additionally, Standard Operating Procedures are provided for all major operations at the facility. 



Additionally, Urethane Polymers International, Inc. has an Emergency Response Plan in place to handle potential emergency situations at this facility.  Key elements of the Emergency Response Plan include specific steps that Urethane Polymers International, Inc. management expects its employees to take to protect the health of employees, visitors and the neighbors. The Emergency Plan is reviewed and updated periodically to ensure that it remains current.



Stationary Source and Regulated Substance 



All storage and processes using Toluene Di-isocyanate are conducted inside the building at Urethane Polymers International, Inc.  All drums of TDI are stored in a dedicated Storage Room and are moved to the processing area when needed.



Five-Year Accident History 



There have not been any significant releases to the environment of Toluene Di-isocyanate vapors in the past 5 years (April 2014 to April 2019).

Planned Changes to Improve Safety 



All industry and manufacturer recommended practices are followed to minimize the risk of a release. There are no planned changes at this time.
